comment_regular_data.body:
Not sure if I can write a test for this. @Grueslayer do you have any ideas. Here's an example of a current test:

```lua
      it('handle input', function()
        eq('hellocat', system({ 'cat' }, { stdin = 'hellocat', text = true }).stdout)
      end)
```

We (@Grueslayer and me) had this issue with nodejs and `npm` not being found on a windows systems. Idk if you have windows specific tests.

For ref: https://github.com/mistweaverco/kulala.nvim/issues/304

So our problematic code on windows was something like `vim.system({"npm", "-v"})`.

Idk about other programs that might have problems with that call, but npm sure does.

---

Feels hacky, but you could put an `awesomeapp.bat` in `C:\windows\system32\` and an `awesomeapp` in `/usr/bin` and just echo `1` and test that both these calls succeed. :see_no_evil:

> Feels hacky, but you could put a awesomeapp.bat in C:\windows\system32\ and a awesomeapp in /usr/bin and just echo 1 and test that both these calls succeed. ðŸ™ˆ

Good idea this should work well since we can just create a temp dir and add that to PATH.
@lewis6991 As in my description, winrm.cmd should be available in default windows installation:
Preferably the test should spawn something that is benign.
Might be worth setting hide too if .cmd is used implicity. See https://github.com/mfussenegger/nvim-lint/pull/649

~You mean special case `cmd.exe`?~

EDIT: we already do.

I'm having problems with the test:

```lua
    it('can resolve windows command extentions.', function()
      t.write_file('test.bat', '')
      system_sync({ 'chmod', '+x', 'test.bat' })
      system_sync({ './test' })
    end)
```
is erroring with:

```
test\functional\testnvim.lua:950: Error executing lua: D:\a\neovim\neovim\runtime/lua/vim/_system.lua:253: EFTYPE: inappropriate file type or format
stack traceback:
	[C]: in function 'error'
	D:\a\neovim\neovim\runtime/lua/vim/_system.lua:253: in function 'spawn'
	D:\a\neovim\neovim\runtime/lua/vim/_system.lua:342: in function 'system'
	test/functional\lua\system_spec.lua:10: in function 'f'
	test\functional\testnvim.lua:850: in function 'handler'
	[string "<nvim>"]:1: in main chunk

stack traceback:
	test\functional\testnvim.lua:950: in function 'system_sync'
	test/functional\lua\system_spec.lua:120: in function <test/functional\lua\system_spec.lua:117>
```


I don't know, use or have access to a windows machine so I'm a bit stuck here.

@dundargoc HALP!

@lewis6991 You need at least have a content in your BAT file which could be executed, like

```
@echo off
echo Hello World
```
with an empty file you'll get an error.

I don't know your test framework but maybe you need to use Windows backslashes for path separation.

Let's assume you created a file `test.bat` with the above content in the current directory (which is e.g. `c:\temp\`) and use the following vim commands:

```vim
:cd c:\Temp\
:lua print(vim.inspect(vim.system({ vim.fn.exepath(".\\test") })))
```

everything runs fine (as your fix does the same, it should run without the extra call in the arguments)

title: fix(vim.system): resolve executable paths on windows
